page.title: 04LANDSCAPE The sea wall
page.content: The sea wall at Broomhill Sands runs from The Suttons to Broomhill Farm and is necessary at that point because the sea is eroding there. The pre-war wall was of clay and faggots with timber groynes, but due to neglect of the structure in World War II it was replaced with a clay wall with steel sheet piling on the seaward side. Since l960 the coast defence authority have transported shingle from Dungeness to Broomhill to maintain the beach in front of the wall. This beach, by the action of the sea, drifts from Broomhill to Dungeness, whence it returns by lorry. The area to the west of this section of sea wall is a natural sand trap which is constantly being built up by the movement of sand in the wind. The whole area is more popular for shrimping than fishing.
